elements.content: A series of copper coordination polymers of [Cu3(OH)2­(5-iipa)2­(phen)3­(H2O)­·4.5(H2O)] n (1) [Cu(5-iipa)­(phen)­(H2O)] n (2), [Cu(5-iipa)­(bpe)­·2(H2O)] n (3), [Cu(5-iipa)­(p-bix)] n (4), [Cu(5-iipa)­(bbi)] n (5), [Cu2(5-iipa)2­(bbi)­·0.5(H2O)] n (6), and [Cu(5-iipa)­(bpp)­·H2O] n (7) (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)­ethane, p-bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene, bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)­bis(imidazole), bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane) were hydro(solvo)thermally synthesized through the reaction of divalent copper salts, 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-H2iipa), and N-donor ancillary ligands. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses on these complexes revealed that noncovalent interactions were found to be predominant in constructing these supramolecular architectures. Compounds 1–5 all possess three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structures based on O···I, I···I, I···π, and π···π interactions. Compound 6 exhibits a complicated three-dimensional (3D) framework with a new (6·72)2­(63·72·8)2­(63·78·82·92) topology, while 7 features a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating network with a (4,4)-connected (3.85)­(32·83·9) topology. A systematically structural description of these polymers indicates both halogen-related interactions and N-donor auxiliary ligands have a significant effect on the coordination network assembly. Their thermal analysis, X-ray diffraction, and UV–vis absorption spectra have also been investigated as well.

Results demonstrated that both halogen-related interactions and N-donor auxiliary ligands have a significant effect on the coordination network assembly.

elements.content: Great interest has been focused on halogen-bonding interactions in many fields, especially in the crystal engineering of organic and organometallic compounds because of the outlook for halogen bonding in controlling the arrangement and packing of organic and organometallic moieties. Halogen bonds (XBs), namely, are the interactions in which halogen atoms function as electrophilic species. XBs can be described in general as D···X–Y, where X is the electrophilic halogen atom (Lewis acid, XB donor), D is a donor of electron density (Lewis base, XB acceptor), and Y is a carbon, nitrogen, or halogen atom, etc. Compared with conventionally used strong intermolecular forces, such as hydrogen bond and π–π stacking, halogen-related interactions including halogen bonding as well as related halogen···halogen and halogen···π intermolecular interactions exhibit characteristics comparably in regard to directionality and strength in crystal engineering. Halogen bonding impacts in many research fields such as the control of intermolecular recognition and self-assembly processes. And such interaction also can influence the properties of nonlinear optical (NLO) materials, liquid crystals, magnetic and conducting materials, supramolecular organic conductors, anion receptor, and biological systems owning to its potential in drug design.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Great interest has been focused on halogen-bonding interactions in many fields, especially in the crystal engineering of organic and organometallic compounds because of the outlook for halogen bonding in controlling the arrangement and packing of organic and organometallic moieties. Halogen bonds (XBs), namely, are the interactions in which halogen atoms function as electrophilic species. XBs can be described in general as D⋅⋅⋅X-Y, where X is the electrophilic halogen atom (Lewis acid, XB donor), D is a donor of electron density (Lewis base, XB acceptor), and Y is a carbon, nitrogen, or halogen atom, etc. Compared with conventionally used strong intermolecular forces, such as hydrogen bond and π-π stacking, halogen-related interactions including halogen bonding as well as related halogen⋅⋅⋅halogen and halogen⋅⋅⋅π intermolecular interactions exhibit characteristics comparably in regard to directionality and strength in crystal engineering. Halogen bonding impacts in many research fields such as the control of intermolecular recognition and self-assembly processes. And such interaction also can influence the properties of nonlinear optical (NLO) materials, liquid crystals, magnetic and conducting materials, supramolecular organic conductors, anion receptor, and biological systems owning to its potential in drug design.

elements.content: The self-assembly of coordination polymers is influenced by many factors such as the coordinating propensities of the ligands, the geometric preference of metal ions, and their relative stoichiometries as well as templates, reaction temperature, pH value, and solvent systems. One approach is to perform reactions with mixed-ligands such as polycarboxylate and N-containing ligands in the same system, and a great number of new intriguing structures are obtained, which indicates that the introduction of N-containing auxiliary ligands into a metal-polycarboxylate system often leads to structural changes and affords new frameworks.

elements.content: In our latest works, we reported a series of supramolecular complexes based on 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (5-H2iipa) using many different metal ions and different ancillary nitrogen liagnds. The investigation of these complexes revealed that solvent molecules can definitely influence the halogen bonding in the architectures, and the use of auxiliary ligands is also an effective method for the construction of coordination polymers. In order to investigate the characteristics of 5-H2iipa and the effect of N-donor auxiliary ligands in constructing supramolecular architectures more systematically, we selected transition metal Cu(II) and 5-H2iipa, and rationally tuned the rigidity of nitrogen ligands with the expectation of obtaining different coordination polymers. In this paper, we report the syntheses and structures of seven coordination polymers which were obtained by reaction of Cu(II), 5-H2iipa, and selected N-containing auxiliary ligands: [Cu3(OH)2­(5-iipa)2­(phen)3­(H2O)­·4.5(H2O)] n (1) [Cu(5-iipa)­(phen)­(H2O)] n (2), [Cu(5-iipa)­(bpe)­·2(H2O)] n (3), [Cu(5-iipa)­(p-bix)] n (4), [Cu(5-iipa)­(bbi)] n (5), [Cu2(5-iipa)2­(bbi)­·0.5(H2O)] n (6), and [Cu(5-iipa)­(bpp)­·H2O] n (7). Halogen-related interactions have been found in all the structures 1–7 and play different roles in the assembly of these polymers.

elements.content: 5-Iodo-isophthalic acid was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm–1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for compounds 1–7 were measured at 293 K on a Rigaku D/max-3B diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5406 Å). The crushed single crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanning from 5 to 50 °C with a step of 0.1°/s. Solid UV–visible spectra were obtained in the 200–800 nm range on a JASCO UVIDEC-660 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

5-Iodo-isophthalic acid was prepared according to the literature. All other starting materials were analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N was performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm-1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) for compounds 1-7 were measured at 293 K on a Rigaku D/max-3B diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5406 Å). The crushed single crystalline powder samples were prepared by crushing the crystals and scanning from 5 to 50 °C with a step of 0.1°/s. Solid UV-visible spectra were obtained in the 200-800 nm range on a JASCO UVIDEC-660 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of 5-iodo-isophthalic acid (0.0146 g, 0.05 mmol), phenanthroline (0.0099 g, 0.05 mmol), CuCl2·6H2O (0.0085 g, 0.05 mmol), and LiOH·H2O(0.0042 g, 0.1 mmol) in 7 mL of distilled water at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooling to room temperature. Blue rectangular crystals of 1 were obtained in 73% yield based on copper. Anal. Calcd for C104H86Cu6I4­N12O31 (2888.69): C, 43.24; H, 2.97; N, 5.81%. Found: C, 43.32; H, 2.90; N, 5.75%. IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3417(m), 3051(w), 1599(s), 1544(m), 1518(m), 1424(m), 1339(s), 1140(w), 1104(w), 852(m), 775(m), 722(s), 707(s).

elements.content: Single crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were used for intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. The approximate positions of the water H atoms, obtained from a difference Fourier map, were restrained to ideal configuration of the water molecule and fixed in the final stages of refinement. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The restraints (SIMU and DFIX) were applied in the unreasonable benzene ring and disordered carboxylic groups, and the alerts in the complexes can be attributed to weak diffraction resulting from poor quality of the crystal itself. In compounds 5 and 7, both the site occupancies of Cu1 and Cu2 are 0.5. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1–7 are listed in Table and .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were used for intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordination water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. The approximate positions of the water H atoms, obtained from a difference Fourier map, were restrained to ideal configuration of the water molecule and fixed in the final stages of refinement. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The restraints (SIMU and DFIX) were applied in the unreasonable benzene ring and disordered carboxylic groups, and the alerts in the complexes can be attributed to weak diffraction resulting from poor quality of the crystal itself. In compounds 5 and 7, both the site occupancies of Cu1 and Cu2 are 0.5. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1-7 are listed in Table  and .

For a systematic investigation of the characteristics of 5-H2iipa, our strategy was to prepare a series of Cu(II) complexes by changing systematically the auxiliary coligands including phen, bpe, p-bix, bbi, and bpp ligands with different N,N′-donor separations. At first, NaOH was used as the base to neutralize the 5-iodo-isophthalic acid. However, we found out that only single crystals of 2–4 and 7 could be obtained, and 5 and 6 were blue precipitate. Owning to the different ionic radius and metallicity of Li+ and Na+, LiOH and NaOH have a different basicity. Taking account of this, LiOH was also introduced into the synthetic process as the base. It was a pleasure to find that single crystals of 5 and 6 were obtained. Moreover, the new phase of complex 1 different from 2 was also obtained. This phenomenon obviously demonstrated that the substitution of one base for another can make a difference in forming coordination polymers. In addition, compounds 5 and 6 were synthesized in a different molar ratio of metal–ligand. Generally, many factors can affect the presynthesis process of coordination polymers, and it remains a long-term challenge to construct coordination polymers with desirable structures and properties.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of the Complexes

For a systematic investigation of the characteristics of 5-H2iipa, our strategy was to prepare a series of Cu(II) complexes by changing systematically the auxiliary coligands including phen, bpe, p-bix, bbi, and bpp ligands with different N,N'-donor separations. At first, NaOH was used as the base to neutralize the 5-iodo-isophthalic acid. However, we found out that only single crystals of 2-4 and 7 could be obtained, and 5 and 6 were blue precipitate. Owning to the different ionic radius and metallicity of Li+ and Na+, LiOH and NaOH have a different basicity. Taking account of this, LiOH was also introduced into the synthetic process as the base. It was a pleasure to find that single crystals of 5 and 6 were obtained. Moreover, the new phase of complex 1 different from 2 was also obtained. This phenomenon obviously demonstrated that the substitution of one base for another can make a difference in forming coordination polymers. In addition, compounds 5 and 6 were synthesized in a different molar ratio of metal-ligand. Generally, many factors can affect the presynthesis process of coordination polymers, and it remains a long-term challenge to construct coordination polymers with desirable structures and properties.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 1 consists of three crystallographically independent Cu(II) centers, two hydroxyl groups, two 5-iipa2– ligands, three phen ligands, one coordinated water molecule and four and a half solvent water molecules. As shown in Figure a, all three Cu(II) ions are five-coordinated with slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometry, but their environments are little different. Cu1 is coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different 5-iipa2– anions, one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from phen, while Cu2 and Cu3 are both in an environment supplied by one oxygen atom from 5-iipa2– anion, two bridging hydroxyl oxygen atoms, and two nitrogen atoms from phen ligand. Addison has defined a geometric parameter τ5 (τ5 = [(β – α)/60], where β and α are the angles between the donor atoms forming the basal plane in square-pyramidal geometry) to a five-coordinate metal system as an index of the degree of distortion. The τ5 parameter for Cu1 and Cu2 is 0.0586 and 0.1351 (for ideal square-pyramidal geometry, τ5 = 0). The coordination angles around Cu3 (τ5 = 0.0247) vary from 81.5° to 176.3° with the bond angles of O9–Cu3–N6 and O9–Cu3–N5 being ca. 176.3° and 174.8°, respectively. Bond valence sum calculation shows that the value for the calculated oxidation state of Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 is 1.854, 1.865, and 1.726, respectively, which is consistent with the formula of compound 1 (Table S1 in the ). Two adjacent asymmetric units are connected via face-to-face π···π interaction [intercentroid distance: 3.528 Å (N3-ring–phenyl ring)] forming a subunit, and the short distance of Cu3···O9 (2.700 Å) can be taken as a weak coordination interaction (Figure b). Connection of neighboring subunits through weak O···I interactions generates an infinite chain with the shortest O···I distance of 3.144 Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (ca. 3.50 Å), as shown in Figure c. These chains are further extended to a layer through I···π interactions (I–centroid distance, 4.001 Å) between the iodine atoms and the neighboring aromatic rings from 5-iipa2– ligands (Figure d). Then the adjacent layers are associated together through π···π interactions (centroid–centroid distance, 3.532 Å) between phen ligands resulting in a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure e). In addition, it is worth pointing out that the 3D supramolecular framework is also reinforced by the hydrogen-bonded clusters () of water molecules and the carboxylic oxygen atoms. The parameters of the hydrogen bonds are listed in .

elements.content: When NaOH instead of LiOH was used in the synthetic procedure, we got complex 2 whose structure is completely different from that of 1. Bond valence sum calculations give a value of 1.785 for the copper atom, which leads to a valence Cu(II) compound with a formula of [Cu(5-iipa)­(phen)­(H2O)] n . As illustrated in Figure a, The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of one Cu(II) ion, one 5-iipa2– ligand, one phen ligand, and one coordinated water molecule. The Cu(II) ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two 5-iipa2– ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and two nitrogen atoms from the chelating phen ligand to achieve a distorted square pyramidal geometry with a Addison trigonality factor τ = 0.1423. Each 5-iipa2– ligand links two Cu(II) atoms in the μ2-bridging mode with both carboxylates in monodentate fashion to form an infinite chain which is stabilized by O1W–H1WB···O1#1 hydrogen bonds (O1W–O1#1 2.593 Å, symmetry code: x + 1, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2.). It should be noted that such linkage of metal and ligand results in a unique step-like chain with the torsion angles of 176° (C3–C8–O2–Cu1′) and 84.7° (C5–C7–O4–Cu1) (Figure b). Interestingly, the phenyl ring of 5-iipa2– is almost parallel to the plane of corresponding phen molecule with the dihedral angle of ca. 11°, while the plane of C7O4Cu1 has dihedral angles of ca. 83° with the planes of the phen ligands, indicating they are almost mutually perpendicular. Thus, in the chain the 5-iipa2– ligands and the phen ligands are located at the opposite sides of the metal centers. The chains are associated together through the interchain hydrogen bonds (O1W–O3#2 2.616 Å, symmetry code: −x, −y + 1, −z + 1) in a reverse parallel fashion to give rise to a 2D layer (Figure c). Additional investigation for this structure indicates that the 2D layers are extended to a 3D supramolecular structure by weak I···I interactions with a distance of 3.993 Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (ca. 4.12 Å) (Figure d). We have previously reported three different coordination polymers, namely, [Zn2(5-iipa)2­(phen)2­(H2O)] n , [Cd2(5-iipa)2­(phen)2] n , and [Mn2­(5-iipa)2­(phen)2] n . The structures of these coordination polymers all differ from compound 1. This can be traced to the differences of metal cations and the bases used.

elements.content: Complex 3 exhibits a 3D supramolecular structure based on interlayer I···π interactions. The X-ray crystal structure analysis shows that compound 3 crystallizes in a triclinic crystal system with Pi̅ space group. The oxidation state of the Cu(II) atom was established by a value 1.787 of bond valence sum calculations (Table S3 in the ). The asymmetric unit of 3 is composed of one six-coordinated Cu(II) center, one 5-iipa2– anion, one bpe ligand, and two lattice water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Cu(II) ion is in a twisting octahedral coordination environment with the bond angles spanning from 87.6(2) to 178.2(2)°, and it is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from three 5-iipa2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bpe molecules. In 3, each 5-iipa2– anion has a μ3-η2:η1 connection mode; one of the carboxylate groups adopts μ1-η1:η1-chelating coordination mode, and the other one is in μ2-η1:η1-bridging mode. Pairs of symmetry-related 5-iipa2– ligands act as bridges joining adjacent Cu(II) pairs to give a [Cu2(5-iipa)2] n double chain (Figure b) along the b axis. Then, such chains are further linked by bpe ligands running along the c axis to furnish a dimer-based (4,4) layer, as illustrated in Figure c. However, these compounds sometimes show (6,3)- or (3,6)-connected layers. For example, Du et al. have reported two coordination frameworks with a benzene-1,2,3-tricarboxylate tecton and flexible dipyridyl coligand, in two crystallographically distinct 2D polymeric motifs are (4,4)- and (6,3)-connected layers. Moreover, the hydrogen chains connected with the metal centers by carboxylic O1 atoms () to reinforce the layer structure. Additional investigation of this structure indicates that adjacent layers are interlinked by interlayer I···π interactions formed by the iodine atom and the neighboring phenyl ring of another 5-iipa2– anion (I–centroid: 3.846 Å) (Figure d), which result in a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: When a similar semirigid N-donor ligand p-bix, instead of bpe, was taken into the synthesis, a different 3D supramolecular architecture was obtained. The oxidation state of the Cu(II) atom was established by bond valence sum calculations (Table S4 in the ). As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one Cu(II) ion, one 5-iipa2– ligand, and one p-bix ligand. The Cu(II) ion is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different p-bix ligands, and four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three different 5-iipa2– anions to form a distorted octahedral geometry. Four atoms O1, O2C, O3B, and O4B comprise the equatorial plane, while N1 and N3A occupy the axial positions with the N1–Cu1–N3A angles of 178.1°. The 5-iipa2– ligand shows μ3-bridging coordination mode with one carboxylate group bridging two Cu(II) ions and the other one attaching one Cu(II) center in a bidentate chelating fashion. Two kinds of 5-iipa2– anions and Cu(II) cations are interlinked by alternate means with the Cu···Cu distance being ca. 4.553 Å and 7.389 Å, respectively, to form a double chain. Then, p-bix ligands connect 5-iipa-Cu double chains in μ2-bridged mode forming a (4,4) layer structure (Figure b). It is worth noting that the distance between the I atoms and O atoms from carboxylate groups of 5-iipa2– anions is 3.483 Å, which is shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two atoms (ca. 3.5 Å), indicating the existence of the O···I interactions. As shown in Figure c, the 2D covalent layers are interconnected through a pair of symmetry-related O···I interactions to yield a 3D supramolecular structure. Of particular interest, owing to the great torsion angle of p-bix and Cu···Cu distance, there is unoccupied void space existing in the 3D supramolecular structure. Approximately 5.2% of the crystal volume is occupied by the voids with a volume of ca. 56.5 Å3 in each cell unit (1096.1 Å3) based on a PLATON calculation.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Figure a, this compound consists of two kinds of Cu(II) cations, one kind of 5-iipa2– anion, and two kinds of bbi ligands. Both the site occupancies of Cu1 and Cu2 are 0.5. Each metal center is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from different 5-iipa2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two symmetry related bbi ligands completing a slightly distorted quadrangular [N2O2] coordination geometry. The bond angles of O2–Cu2–O2B, N1–Cu2–N1B are ca. 164.5°, 171.2° respectively, both the N3–Cu1–N3A and O4–Cu1–O4A bond angles are 180° (). Bond valence sum calculation shows that the value for the calculated oxidation state of Cu1 and Cu2 is 1.631 and 1.618, respectively, which is consistent with the formula of compound 5. Each 5-iipa2– ligand acts as a μ2-bridge linking Cu1 and Cu2 atoms via two monodentate carboxylate groups to form an infinite Cu–5-iipa2– chain. Such chains are bridged by two kinds of bbi ligands along the c direction to result in a wavy net incorporating a window of ca. 9.49 Å × 14.25 Å based on the Cu···Cu distances. One kind of the bbi ligand (N1, N2) adopts a TGT conformation with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of ca. 69.1°, while the other kind of bbi (N3, N4) adopts a TTT conformation with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of 0°. It should be noticed that to minimize the large void cavities and stabilize the network, each layer is interpenetrated by other two equivalent nets in a parallel fashion leading to the formation of an unusual 3-fold interpenetrated 2D → 2D sheet, as depicted in Figure b. To better understand the structure of compound 5, the topological analysis approach is employed. As shown in Figure c, if the metal centers and the ligands can be seen as nodes and rods respectively, the whole architecture can be simplified as a 3-fold interpenetrating structure by the 4-connected network. Such layers from different sheets are united together to yield a 3D supramolecular structure of 3-fold interpenetration through mutual I···π interactions with the distance of 3.724 Å between iodine atoms and the adjacent aromatic rings from 5-iipa2– (Figure d). In our previous work, we reported a cobaltic coordination polymer [Co(5-iipa)­(bbi)­·3(H2O)] n which features a rare 3-fold interpenetrating 3D supramolecular architecture based on I···I interactions. The difference of these two compounds can be attributed to the different atomic radius and coordination numbers of cobalt(II) and copper(II).

X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that compound 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Figure a, this compound consists of two kinds of Cu(II) cations, one kind of 5-iipa2- anion, and two kinds of bbi ligands. Both the site occupancies of Cu1 and Cu2 are 0.5. Each metal center is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from different 5-iipa2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two symmetry related bbi ligands completing a slightly distorted quadrangular [N2O2] coordination geometry. The bond angles of O2-Cu2-O2B, N1-Cu2-N1B are ca. 164.5°, 171.2° respectively, both the N3-Cu1-N3A and O4-Cu1-O4A bond angles are 180° (). Bond valence sum calculation shows that the value for the calculated oxidation state of Cu1 and Cu2 is 1.631 and 1.618, respectively, which is consistent with the formula of compound 5. Each 5-iipa2- ligand acts as a μ2-bridge linking Cu1 and Cu2 atoms via two monodentate carboxylate groups to form an infinite Cu-5-iipa2- chain. Such chains are bridged by two kinds of bbi ligands along the c direction to result in a wavy net incorporating a window of ca. 9.49 Å × 14.25 Å based on the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances. One kind of the bbi ligand (N1, N2) adopts a TGT conformation with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of ca. 69.1°, while the other kind of bbi (N3, N4) adopts a TTT conformation with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of 0°. It should be noticed that to minimize the large void cavities and stabilize the network, each layer is interpenetrated by other two equivalent nets in a parallel fashion leading to the formation of an unusual 3-fold interpenetrated 2D → 2D sheet, as depicted in Figure b. To better understand the structure of compound 5, the topological analysis approach is employed. As shown in Figure c, if the metal centers and the ligands can be seen as nodes and rods respectively, the whole architecture can be simplified as a 3-fold interpenetrating structure by the 4-connected network. Such layers from different sheets are united together to yield a 3D supramolecular structure of 3-fold interpenetration through mutual I⋅⋅⋅π interactions with the distance of 3.724 Å between iodine atoms and the adjacent aromatic rings from 5-iipa2- (Figure d). In our previous work, we reported a cobaltic coordination polymer [Co(5-iipa)(bbi)⋅3(H2O)] n  which features a rare 3-fold interpenetrating 3D supramolecular architecture based on I⋅⋅⋅I interactions. The difference of these two compounds can be attributed to the different atomic radius and coordination numbers of cobalt(II) and copper(II).

The balls on the wave crest and trough represent Cu2 and other balls represent Cu1 atoms.) (d) A set of the 3D superamolecular network. (The two-colored dotted lines represent I···π interactions.)

elements.content: The structure of compound 6 exhibits a 3D framework with a new Schläfli symbol of (6·72)2­(63·72·8)2­(63·78·82·92) topology. The asymmetric unit of compound 6 contains two crystallographically nonequivalent Cu(II) atoms, two 5-iipa2– anions, one bbi ligand, and half water molecule. The coordination environment of the Cu(II) center is represented in Figure a, and the two independent metal atoms are both five-coordinated but adopt a different coordination geometry. Cu1 sits in an irregular trigonal bipyramidal geometry composed of three oxygen atoms from two crystallographically nonequivalent 5-iipa2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from different bbi ligands, while Cu2 is in a slightly distored square-pyramid environment (τ = 0.0031) supplied by five oxygen atoms from five 5-iipa2– anions. The oxidation states of the Cu(II) atoms were established by bond valence sum calculations (Table S6 in the ). One kind of 5-iipa2– ligand (I1) acts as μ4-bridge connecting one Cu1 atom and three Cu2 atoms with both carboxylate groups in bidentate fashion, and the other kind of 5-iipa2– ligand (I2) exhibits a μ3-bridging mode with one carboxylate group bridging two Cu2 atoms and the other one attaching one Cu1 center in bidentate chelating fashion. A pair of Cu2 atoms are bridged by two pairs of symmetry-related carboxylate groups (C7, C15) to form a [Cu2(CO2)4] cluster with the separation of Cu···Cu being 2.641 Å, and such clusters are expanded into a 2D layer in the bc plane through sharing 5-iipa2– ligands (I1) (Figure b). As shown in Figure c, the layers are interlinked by Cu1 atoms which act as nodes to link the [Cu2(CO2)4] clusters from different layers through the I2 containing ligands along the a direction to generate a novel 3D architecture, which is different from the structure of the coordination polymer constructed by Cu(II), bbi, and isophthalate anion. Hydrogen bonding between solvent water molecules and the carboxylic O atoms was observed to stabilize the structure (Figure S3 in the ). The distance of 3.807 Å, 3.810 Å between I2 and aromatic rings (C2–C3, C11–C12, respectively) which come from different 5-iipa2– ligands suggests that there are weak I···π interactions which reinforce the 3D structure. The bbi ligand adopts a TTT conformation with the dihedral angles between the imidazole rings of ca. 26.7° bridging two Cu1 cations along the c direction (Figure d). A better understanding of this complicated structure can be achieved via topological considerations. If the 5-iipa2– ligand (I1) is regarded as a three-connected node linking two [Cu2(CO2)4] clusters and one Cu1 atom, Cu1 atom is as a four-connected node linking two other Cu1 atoms through bbi ligands and one [Cu2(CO2)4] cluster through 5-iipa2– ligands (I1) as well as one I2 containing ligands, [Cu2(CO2)4] cluster as a six-connected node by connecting to four 5-iipa2– ligands (I1) and two Cu1 atoms through I2 containing ligands, the I2 containing ligand and bbi as rods, the 3D structure of 6 can be classified as a (3,4,6)-connected lattice with a (6·72)2­(63·72·8)2­(63·78·82·92) Schläfli symbol which represents a new network topology (Figure e), as determined by TOPOS software.

elements.content: Compound 7 displays a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating network. It crystallizes in an orthorhombic symmetry with space group Pnma and has a 3D coordination network. The oxidation states of the Cu1 and Cu2 atoms were established by the value 1.773 and 1.748 of bond valence sum calculations (Table S7 in the ), respectively. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 7 contains two kinds of crystallographic independent Cu(II) centers, two kinds of different 5-iipa2– ligands, and one kind of bpp ligand. Both the site occupancies of Cu1 and Cu2 are 0.5. Cu1 with distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N1, N1B) from two bpp ligands and four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3A, O4A) from two different 5-iipa2– anions. Meanwhile, Cu2 is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (N2, N2C) and four oxygen atoms (O5, O6, O5C, O6C) from two separate 5-iipa2– ligands to form a distorted octahedral geometry. At the same time, each 5-iipa2– anion adopts μ2-η1:η1-bridging mode to link two Cu(II) centers. As depicted in Figure d, it clearly shows the framework structure is surrounding a single channel, which is an open-ended, hollow tube extending along the b-axis. In Figure b, each tube consists of octanuclear metallomacrocycles composed of four 5-iipa2– units, four bpp ligands, two Cu1 metal centers, and six Cu2 centers. In this metallomacrocycle, Cu1 and Cu2 metal ions are linked together by bpp ligands along the b axis to form the double Cu–bpp chains. These chains are further linked via Cu2–5-iipa2– chains completed by Cu2 atoms and 5-iipa2– ligands which take bidentate chelating coordination mode along the a axis to shape the tube (Figure c). The 3D framework can be considered to consist of a tubular channel. Each tubular channel is linked with other channels via 5-iipa2– ligands in the ac plane (Figure d). A better understanding of this framework can be achieved via topological considerations. Considering the Cu1 and Cu2 centers as 4-connected nodes, the bpp ligands and 5-iipa2– ligands as rods, a (4,4)-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of (3.85)(32.83.9) topology can be invoked by TOPOS software. It is noticeable that such three homogeneous 3D single nets are interlocked with each other by hydrogen bonding (), thus directly leading to the formation of a three-dimensional 3-fold interpenetrated architecture, as shown in Figure e. In addition, the distance between the I atom and an adjacent phenyl ring of the 5-iipa2‑ ligand from another chain is 3.651 Å, which is indicative of weak I···π interaction. The iodine-related interactions in the structure of complex 7 only reinforce the structure. Interestingly, if the roles of bpp ligands are omitted, there still exists a 3D supramolecular structure through I···π interactions (Figure f).

elements.content: Organic ligands with carboxylate groups have been successfully employed in the generation of many interesting systems exhibiting multidimensional architectures because of their various coordination modes. Moreover, when the different groups were added to these ligands, different structures were obtained. The presence of the -Me, -MeO, or -C(CH3)3 groups in dicarboxylate ligands produce more steric hindrance, which can greatly influence the whole structure of the complexes. And -OH, -COOH, -NH2, and -NO2 can afford hydrogen bonding which may help to increase the dimensionality of the structures and produce novel architectures. We use the rigid 5-iodo-isophthalic acid as ligands in this work, because it contains two carboxylate groups that can provide versatile coordination modes, and the iodine atom that can affect the assembly of supramolecular structures by forming halogen bonds. In this paper, halogen-related interactions have been found in compounds 1–7, indicating 5-H2iipa is a good ligand which can introduce halogen bonding into metal–organic complexes. The related information of intermolecular interactions containing iodine atom in the above structures are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Organic ligands with carboxylate groups have been successfully employed in the generation of many interesting systems exhibiting multidimensional architectures because of their various coordination modes. Moreover, when the different groups were added to these ligands, different structures were obtained. The presence of the -Me, -MeO, or -C(CH3)3 groups in dicarboxylate ligands produce more steric hindrance, which can greatly influence the whole structure of the complexes. And -OH, -COOH, -NH2, and -NO2 can afford hydrogen bonding which may help to increase the dimensionality of the structures and produce novel architectures. We use the rigid 5-iodo-isophthalic acid as ligands in this work, because it contains two carboxylate groups that can provide versatile coordination modes, and the iodine atom that can affect the assembly of supramolecular structures by forming halogen bonds. In this paper, halogen-related interactions have been found in compounds 1-7, indicating 5-H2iipa is a good ligand which can introduce halogen bonding into metal-organic complexes. The related information of intermolecular interactions containing iodine atom in the above structures are listed in Table .

Results also revealed that the auxiliary neutral ligands play an important role in determining the structural diversity in coordination polymers: Length of the coligands can definitely influence the frameworks such as phen, bpe, bix, bpp, and bbi in compounds 1–7. The addition of phenanthroline makes it difficult to form high-dimensional structure because of the large steric hindrance of phen, which is proved by compounds 1 and 2. Compound 1 exhibits a trinuclear copper(II) complex, while compound 2 shows a unique step-like chain. The rigidity and extensibility of the secondary ligands bpe and bix made compounds 3 and 4 extend to a 2D covalent layer compared to 1 and 2. Generally, when long linkers such as bbi and bpp are introduced into the assembly of coordination polymers, the resulting networks usually assumed uncommon types of entanglements, as shown in 5–7. Compound 5 exhibits a 3-fold parallel interpenetrated 2D → 2D network because of its flexibility and conformational freedom from a -(CH2)4- spacer of bbi ligand. However, different from 5, in complex 6, Cu atoms have been bridged by 5-iipa2– ligands to form a 3D framework, and the bbi ligands only filled in the cavity to stabilize the framework, which indicates that the change of metal–ligand ratio can also decide the structure’s spatial degree. In the same way, due to the conformational flexibility of bpp, a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating network is found in compound 7. It is obvious that the length and configuration of the auxiliary ligands play an important role in the final results.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1–7 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1–7 are shown in Figure S4, . The TG curve for 1 shows the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 40–107 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules as well as coordinated water molecules and hydroxyl groups (observed: 4.63% and calculated: 4.60%). Further weight loss observed from 234 °C indicates the decomposition of coordination framework. For complex 2, a gradual weight loss between 32 and 227 °C is attributed to the release of the coordinated water molecules (observed, 3.25%; calculated, 3.26%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 258 °C. For complex 3, a gradual weight loss between 26 and 104 °C is attributed to the release of two uncoordinated water molecules (observed, 6.28%; calculated, 6.27%), and then from 280 °C the host framework started to decompose. The TG curve of 4 shows that the framework collapsed from 299 °C. In the case of compound 5, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 275 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve for 6 shows the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 30–80 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules (observed: 0.46% and calculated: 0.25%). The rapid weight loss was observed from 292 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. The TG curve of 7 displays the first weight loss of 3.14% (calculated: 3.16%) from 25 to 115 °C, corresponding to the loss of one uncoordinated water molecule per formula unit. A gradual weight loss from 215 °C indicates that the compound was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. According to the above thermogravimetric analysis of the seven coordination polymers, the anhydrous composition of these compounds begins to decompose beyond 210 °C; especially the frameworks of 4 and 6 collapsed from 299 and 292 °C, respectively, which indicated the higher thermal stability of these two compounds than others.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis and X-ray Powder Diffraction

Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of complexes 1-7 was performed to study the thermal stability of these polymers. TG curves for complexes 1-7 are shown in Figure S4, . The TG curve for 1 shows the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 40-107 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules as well as coordinated water molecules and hydroxyl groups (observed: 4.63% and calculated: 4.60%). Further weight loss observed from 234 °C indicates the decomposition of coordination framework. For complex 2, a gradual weight loss between 32 and 227 °C is attributed to the release of the coordinated water molecules (observed, 3.25%; calculated, 3.26%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition is observed from 258 °C. For complex 3, a gradual weight loss between 26 and 104 °C is attributed to the release of two uncoordinated water molecules (observed, 6.28%; calculated, 6.27%), and then from 280 °C the host framework started to decompose. The TG curve of 4 shows that the framework collapsed from 299 °C. In the case of compound 5, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 275 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve for 6 shows the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 30-80 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules (observed: 0.46% and calculated: 0.25%). The rapid weight loss was observed from 292 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. The TG curve of 7 displays the first weight loss of 3.14% (calculated: 3.16%) from 25 to 115 °C, corresponding to the loss of one uncoordinated water molecule per formula unit. A gradual weight loss from 215 °C indicates that the compound was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. According to the above thermogravimetric analysis of the seven coordination polymers, the anhydrous composition of these compounds begins to decompose beyond 210 °C; especially the frameworks of 4 and 6 collapsed from 299 and 292 °C, respectively, which indicated the higher thermal stability of these two compounds than others.

As shown in , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns (b) are similar to those in the simulated patterns (a) generated from single-crystal diffraction data, indicating single phases of 1–7 are formed.

elements.content: The solid-state UV/vis spectra of 5-H2iipa and coordination polymers 1–7 are displayed in . Seen from the UV/vis absorption spectra, the 5-H2iipa ligand itself displays weak absorption bands at 317 nm with a weak shoulder band at 379 nm, arising from the π–π* transition of the aromatic rings. These bands are not strongly perturbed upon its coordination to copper(II) in compounds 1–7, suggesting that coordination of the metal ions hardly alters the intrinsic electronic properties of the ligand. In the 500–800 nm region, coordination polymers 1–7 exhibit a broad band: The additional absorption of compound 5 in the visible region was observed at ca. 576 nm. For compound 7, a relatively stronger band centered at ca. 574 nm was observed. The phenomenon may trace back to the central metal atoms of the crystals. These bands in the UV/vis absorption spectra can be attributed to the d–d spin-forbidden transition of the d9 (Cu2+) ion.
elements.clean_text:
UV/vis Absorbance Properties

The solid-state UV/vis spectra of 5-H2iipa and coordination polymers 1-7 are displayed in . Seen from the UV/vis absorption spectra, the 5-H2iipa ligand itself displays weak absorption bands at 317 nm with a weak shoulder band at 379 nm, arising from the π-π* transition of the aromatic rings. These bands are not strongly perturbed upon its coordination to copper(II) in compounds 1-7, suggesting that coordination of the metal ions hardly alters the intrinsic electronic properties of the ligand. In the 500-800 nm region, coordination polymers 1-7 exhibit a broad band: The additional absorption of compound 5 in the visible region was observed at ca. 576 nm. For compound 7, a relatively stronger band centered at ca. 574 nm was observed. The phenomenon may trace back to the central metal atoms of the crystals. These bands in the UV/vis absorption spectra can be attributed to the d-d spin-forbidden transition of the d9 (Cu2+) ion.

elements.content: In summary, on the basis of combination of 5-H2iipa ligand and various N-donor ligands, seven divalent copper coordination polymers 1–7 have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analysis revealed that these compounds exhibit different intriguing supramolecular architectures in which various halogen bonding are found. These results have demonstrated that the presence of iodine atom and carboxylate groups in the same system can lead to crossing-pairing such as O···I halogen bonding, I···I, or I···π interactions ,which are effective and reliable tools in supramolecular coordination assemblies. 5-H2iipa is an effective ligand, which is useful to better understand the synthon selectivity in multifunctional crystal structures. In addition, the role of N-containing auxiliary ligands into a metal-polycarboxylate system often leads to structural changes and affords new frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, on the basis of combination of 5-H2iipa ligand and various N-donor ligands, seven divalent copper coordination polymers 1-7 have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray analysis revealed that these compounds exhibit different intriguing supramolecular architectures in which various halogen bonding are found. These results have demonstrated that the presence of iodine atom and carboxylate groups in the same system can lead to crossing-pairing such as O⋅⋅⋅I halogen bonding, I⋅⋅⋅I, or I⋅⋅⋅π interactions ,which are effective and reliable tools in supramolecular coordination assemblies. 5-H2iipa is an effective ligand, which is useful to better understand the synthon selectivity in multifunctional crystal structures. In addition, the role of N-containing auxiliary ligands into a metal-polycarboxylate system often leads to structural changes and affords new frameworks.

For complex 3, a gradual weight loss between 26 and 104 °C is attributed to the release of two uncoordinated water molecules (observed, 6.28%; calculated, 6.27%), and then from 280 °C the host framework started to decompose. The TG curve of 4 shows that the framework collapsed from 299 °C. In the case of compound 5, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 275 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve for 6 shows the initial weight loss in the temperature range of 30-80 °C, which can be ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules (observed: 0.46% and calculated: 0.25%). The rapid weight loss was observed from 292 °C, which indicated the decomposition of the whole structure. The TG curve of 7 displays the first weight loss of 3.14% (calculated: 3.16%) from 25 to 115 °C, corresponding to the loss of one uncoordinated water molecule per formula unit. A gradual weight loss from 215 °C indicates that the compound was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. According to the above thermogravimetric analysis of the seven coordination polymers, the anhydrous composition of these compounds begins to decompose beyond 210 °C; especially the frameworks of 4 and 6 collapsed from 299 and 292 °C, respectively, which indicated the higher thermal stability of these two compounds than others.
